qa_list.question: What types of support are offered by the Communication Support program?
qa_list.answer: The Communication Support program offers several modes of support, including One-on-one Communication Tutoring (in-person or synchronous Zoom meeting), Video Response (asynchronous feedback within 5 days of scheduled appointment), Group Appointments for peer reviews and collaborative presentation strategies, Workshops on various topics to learn research-backed communication strategies, and Resources such as handouts and videos that explain specific communication strategies.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Language and Cross-Cultural Support at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of Language and Cross-Cultural Support at Carnegie Mellon is to help international students, non-native speakers of English who have attended high school or undergraduate programs in the U.S., hone their language and cross-cultural skills for academic and professional success.

qa_list.question: How can clients make an appointment with a consultant at Communication Support?
qa_list.answer: Clients can make an appointment with a consultant by uploading a draft, instructor prompts, and rubrics when making the appointment. See the appointment types offered here: https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/programs/communication-support/make-an-appointment.html

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Group Appointments in Communication Support?
qa_list.answer: Group Appointments are offered for peer reviews and collaborative presentation strategies.

qa_list.question: Where can students find Workshops on various communication topics at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Students can find Workshops on a variety of topics that help them learn research-backed communication strategies by visiting https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/calendar.html

qa_list.question: What resources are available for students to improve their language and cross-cultural skills at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: Students can find online handouts and videos that concisely explain specific communication strategies by visiting https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/other-resources/index.html

qa_list.question: What percentage of graduate students at Carnegie Mellon are international students?
qa_list.answer: More than 60% of graduate students at Carnegie Mellon are international students.

qa_list.question: Where is the information about Language and Cross-Cultural Support located in the MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The information about Language and Cross-Cultural Support can be found on page 42 of the MLT Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of One-on-one Communication Tutoring in the Communication Support program?
qa_list.answer: One-on-one Communication Tutoring aims to improve the logic, clarity, and flow of writing or presentation and provide expert feedback that will strengthen a project.

qa_list.question: How long does it take for students to receive Video Response feedback from the Communication Support program?
qa_list.answer: Students can expect to receive Video Response feedback within 5 days of their scheduled appointment.

qa_list.question: What services does the Student Academic Success Center offer for International Teaching Assistants (ITAs)?
qa_list.answer: The Student Academic Success Center offers language certification and classes to ensure nonnative English speakers have the necessary proficiency to succeed as teaching assistants in the Carnegie Mellon classroom.

qa_list.question: What kind of tutoring services does Peer Tutoring offer?
qa_list.answer: Peer Tutoring offers weekly one-on-one and small group appointments to students from any discipline who need assistance with a course that may not be supported by other services.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Academic Coaching?
qa_list.answer: Academic Coaching provides holistic one-on-one peer support and group workshops to help students find and implement their conditions for success, focusing on improving time management, productive habits, organization, stress management, and study skills.

qa_list.question: What kind of sessions can students choose from in the Language Development Specialist program?
qa_list.answer: Students can choose from sessions on how to give a strong presentation, writing academic emails, analyzing expectations for clear academic writing, talking about themselves as professionals in the U.S., developing clearer pronunciation, using accurate grammar, and building fluency.

qa_list.question: How can students make an appointment with a Language Development Specialist?
qa_list.answer: Students can make an appointment with a Language Development Specialist to get individualized coaching on language or cross-cultural issues.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Student Academic Success Center's A.2.4.3 Learning Support section?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Student Academic Success Center's A.2.4.3 Learning Support section is to provide peer tutoring and academic coaching services for students who need assistance with courses not supported by other services.

qa_list.question: How can students register for weekly Peer Tutoring appointments?
qa_list.answer: Students can register online through the Student Academic Success website to schedule their weekly tutoring appointments in one-on-one or small group format.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Peer Tutoring at the Student Academic Success Center?
qa_list.answer: Peer Tutoring provides individualized support to students from any discipline who need assistance with a course that may not be supported by other services.

qa_list.question: What kind of support does the Student Academic Success Center offer for International Teaching Assistants (ITAs)?
qa_list.answer: The Student Academic Success Center offers language certification and classes to ensure nonnative English speakers have the necessary proficiency to succeed as teaching assistants in the Carnegie Mellon classroom.

qa_list.question: What services does Academic Coaching provide?
qa_list.answer: Academic Coaching provides holistic one-on-one peer support and group workshops to help students find and implement their conditions for success. They assist students in improving time management, productive habits, organization, stress management, and study skills.

qa_list.question: How can students request support from Academic Coaching?
qa_list.answer: Students will request support through the Academic Success Center website and attend in-person meetings or meet using video and audio conferencing technology to provide all students with support.

qa_list.question: What kind of supplemental offerings does the Student Academic Success team provide?
qa_list.answer: The Student Academic Success team is available to partner with instructors and departments to identify skills or concepts that would benefit from supplemental offerings (workshops, boot camps) to support students’ academic success and learning.

qa_list.question: What kind of skill-building opportunities does the Student Academic Success team convene?
qa_list.answer: The Student Academic Success team is eager to help convene and coordinate outside of the classroom skill-building opportunities that can be open to any student interested in building skill or reinforcing course concept mastery.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about these supplemental offerings?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about these supplemental offerings through the Academic Success Center website and by partnering with instructors and departments.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The MLT Graduate Student Handbook provides information about academic coaching services, workshops, and supplemental offerings to support students' academic success.

qa_list.question: What is the page number of the text where this information can be found?
qa_list.answer: This information can be found on Page 43 of the MLT Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: How does Academic Coaching help students find and implement their conditions for success?
qa_list.answer: Academic Coaching helps students find and implement their conditions for success by providing holistic one-on-one peer support, group workshops, improving time management, productive habits, organization, stress management, and study skills.

qa_list.question: What is the role of Academic Coaching in helping students succeed academically?
qa_list.answer: Academic Coaching plays a crucial role in helping students succeed academically by providing personalized support through one-on-one peer coaching, group workshops, and skill development opportunities.

qa_list.question: What is the main purpose of the Office of Research Integrity & Compliance (ORIC) at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The main purpose of ORIC is to support research conducted by researchers at CMU, ensuring it's done with integrity and in accordance with federal and Pennsylvania regulations.

qa_list.question: What services does Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) provide for students?
qa_list.answer: CaPS provides a safe space where students can talk about academic or personal concerns. They offer immediate support, referrals to counseling within CaPS or other resources at CMU/Pittsburgh community and workshops on mental health topics specifically for graduate students.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Health Services at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Health Services provides medical care to students, including immunizations, allergy injections, and management of chronic illnesses. They also offer health education programs.

qa_list.question: What kind of research misconduct cases does ORIC handle?
qa_list.answer: ORIC handles allegations of research misconduct at CMU.

qa_list.question: How can students make appointments with Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS)?
qa_list.answer: Students can make appointments in person or by telephone at 412-268-2922.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of Health Services' workshops?
qa_list.answer: Health Services offers workshops on mental health topics specifically for graduate students to promote their wellness and provide them with useful information.

qa_list.question: How does ORIC assist researchers at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: ORIC assists researchers by working with them on human subject research, conflicts of interest, responsible conduct of research, export controls, intellectual property rights and regulations, institutional animal care & use.

qa_list.question: What kind of support does Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) provide for students?
qa_list.answer: CaPS provides immediate support to students who are experiencing academic or personal concerns. They also explore further options if needed, such as referrals to counseling within CaPS or other resources.

qa_list.question: What kind of medical services does Health Services provide?
qa_list.answer: Health Services provides a range of medical services including immunizations, allergy injections, and management of chronic illnesses. They also offer health education programs.

qa_list.question: What services does University Health Services (UHS) provide?
qa_list.answer: University Health Services (UHS) provides general medical care, allergy injections, first aid, gynecological care and contraception, on-site pharmaceuticals, nutrition counseling, drug and alcohol abuse assistance.

qa_list.question: Who is responsible for the fees of prescription medications, laboratory tests, diagnostic procedures, and referral to emergency room or specialists?
qa_list.answer: The students are responsible for these costs under their insurance plan.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Student Health Insurance Program administered by UHS?
qa_list.answer: The program offers a high level of coverage in a wide network of health care providers and hospitals for students.

qa_list.question: How can appointments be made at University Health Services (UHS)?
qa_list.answer: Appointments can be made by visiting UHS’s website, walk-in, or by telephone, 412-268-2157.

qa_list.question: What kind of health issues does the registered dietician at UHS assist students with?
qa_list.answer: The registered dietician assists students in addressing nutrition, drug and alcohol, and other healthy lifestyle issues.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Student Health Insurance Plan according to the MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The plan offers a high level of coverage in a wide network of health care providers and hospitals for students.

qa_list.question: Where can students find detailed information about university health insurance requirements and fees?
qa_list.answer: Students should review the UHS website and their insurance plan for detailed information about the university health insurance requirement and fees.

qa_list.question: What kind of care does University Health Services (UHS) provide to students?
qa_list.answer: University Health Services provides general medical care, gynecological care, contraception services, allergy injections, first aid, and on-site pharmaceuticals.

qa_list.question: What is the role of health promotion specialists at UHS?
qa_list.answer: Health promotion specialists assist students with nutrition, drug and alcohol abuse assistance, and other healthy lifestyle issues.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of BeWell@CMU e-newsletter?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of BeWell@CMU e-newsletter is to be a comprehensive resource for CMU regarding all wellness-inspired events, announcements and professional and personal development opportunities.

qa_list.question: What are the initiatives provided by Carnegie Mellon University for students' spiritual growth?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon provides Religious & Spiritual Life Initiatives (RSLI) which offers programs and initiatives that cross traditional religious boundaries in order to increase knowledge of and appreciation for the full diversity of worldview traditions.

qa_list.question: How can students make a connection into a community of faith during their time at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Students can make a connection into a community of faith by reaching out to RSLI staff who are here to support them across the spectrum of religious and spiritual practice.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of University Police at Carnegie Mellon?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of University Police at Carnegie Mellon is not mentioned in the given text.

qa_list.question: How can students sign up for BeWell@CMU e-newsletter?
qa_list.answer: Students can sign up for BeWell@CMU e-newsletter via https://bit.ly/BeWellNewsletter or by contacting the Program Director for Student Affairs Wellness Initiatives, at alusk@andrew.cmu.edu.

qa_list.question: What is the website address of Carnegie Mellon's Religious & Spiritual Life Initiatives?
qa_list.answer: The website address of Carnegie Mellon's Religious & Spiritual Life Initiatives is www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/spirituality.

qa_list.question: What kind of initiatives does the university provide for students' wellness?
qa_list.answer: The university provides a wide variety of wellness, mindfulness and connectedness initiatives designed to help students thrive inside and outside the classroom.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of BeWell@CMU e-newsletter according to the given text?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of BeWell@CMU e-newsletter is to be a comprehensive resource for CMU regarding all wellness-inspired events, announcements and professional and personal development opportunities.

qa_list.question: What kind of support does RSLI staff provide?
qa_list.answer: RSLI staff provides support across the spectrum of religious and spiritual practice for students at CMU.

qa_list.question: Where is the University Police Department located?
qa_list.answer: The University Police Department is located at 4551 Filmore Street.

qa_list.question: What services does the University Police Department provide?
qa_list.answer: The department’s services include police patrols and call response, criminal investigations, fixed officer and foot officer patrols, event security, crime prevention and education programming, and bicycle and laptop registration.

qa_list.question: What can students do to obtain a copy of the annual campus security and fire safety report?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students can obtain a copy by contacting the University Police Department at 412-268-6232.

qa_list.question: Where is the online version of the annual campus security and fire safety report available?
qa_list.answer: The annual security and fire safety report is also available online at https://www.cmu.edu/police/annualreports/.

qa_list.question: What type of information can be found in the MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The MLT Graduate Student Handbook contains information about the University Police Department.

qa_list.question: On which page is the information about the University Police Department located in the MLT Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: Information about the University Police Department can be found on Page 45 of the MLT Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the phone number for the University Police Department?
qa_list.answer: The phone number for the University Police Department is 412-268-2323.

qa_list.question: How many types of crimes are described in the annual campus security and fire safety report?
qa_list.answer: The annual campus security and fire safety report describes the number and type of crimes committed on the campus.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of bicycle registration at the University Police Department?
qa_list.answer: Bicycle registration at the University Police Department serves as a crime prevention measure.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Shuttle and Escort Service at CMU?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Shuttle and Escort Service at CMU is to provide transportation for students, faculty, and community members.

qa_list.question: Where can students find information about academic policies and resources in The WORD?
qa_list.answer: Students can find information about academic policies and resources in The WORD by visiting the following link: http://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/

qa_list.question: What is included in The WORD?
qa_list.answer: The WORD includes information about University-wide academic policies and resources, community policies and resources, and procedures for reviewing possible violations of these standards.

qa_list.question: Why should graduate students refer to The WORD often?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students should refer to The WORD often because it provides them with the tools, guidance, and insights they need to achieve their full potential as members of the Carnegie Mellon community.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Human Subjects in Research section in The WORD?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the Human Subjects in Research section in The WORD is to provide guidelines and policies for research involving human subjects.

qa_list.question: What is the MLT Graduate Student Handbook, and where can it be found?
qa_list.answer: The MLT Graduate Student Handbook is a resource that provides guidelines and policies for graduate students in the Master of Language Teaching (MLT) program. It can be found on page 46.

qa_list.question: What are some of the topics covered in The WORD?
qa_list.answer: The WORD covers a wide range of topics, including but not limited to: Carnegie Mellon Vision, Mission Statement of Assurance, Carnegie Mellon Code Academic Standards, Policies and Procedures, Educational Goals, Academic Disciplinary Actions Overview, Statement on Academic Integrity, Standards for Academic & Creative Life, Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities, Master’s Student Statute of Limitations, Conduct of Classes, Copyright Policy, Cross-college & University Registration, Doctoral Student Status Policy, Evaluation & Certification of English Fluency for Instructors, Final Exams for Graduate Courses, Grading Policies, Intellectual Property Policy, Privacy Rights of Students, and Student’s Rights.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of The WORD in Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of The WORD in Carnegie Mellon University is to serve as the foundation for department and sometimes college handbooks, providing students with information about university-wide academic policies and resources.

qa_list.question: What are some of the procedures used to review possible violations of standards at CMU?
qa_list.answer: Some of the procedures used to review possible violations of standards at CMU include those described in The WORD, which serves as the foundation for department and sometimes college handbooks.

qa_list.question: What is the URL of the Shuttle & Escort Service website?
qa_list.answer: The URL of the Shuttle & Escort Service website is https://www.cmu.edu/parking/shuttle/index.html

doc_text:
project types. Clients can bring in a project at any stage, including brainstorming ideas, organizing thoughts, responding to instructor feedback, or putting finishing touches on the final draft. Support is offered in several modes: o One-on-one Communication Tutoring (in-person or synchronous Zoom meeting): Clients meet with a consultant to improve the logic, clarity, and flow of writing or presentation and receive expert feedback that will strengthen a project. When making an appointment, clients upload a draft, instructor prompts, and rubrics so the consultants can use specific criteria to give relevant feedback. See the appointment types offered here: https://www.cmu.edu/student- success/programs/communication-support/make-an-appointment.html o Video Response (asynchronous): Clients upload documents in advance, then receive a 20 to 30 minute video with a consultant’s feedback. The feedback video will be received within 5 days of the scheduled appointment.
o Group Appointments: Participate with your group to accomplish peer reviews or
focus on collaborative presentation strategies.
o Workshops: Workshops are available on a variety of topics and help attendees
learn research-backed communication strategies. https://www.cmu.edu/student-success/calendar.html
o Resources: An online collection of handouts and videos that concisely explain
specific communication strategies are available. https://www.cmu.edu/student- success/other-resources/index.html
A.2.4.2 Language and Cross-Cultural Support More than 60% of graduate students at Carnegie Mellon are international students, and others are non-native speakers of English who have attended high school or undergraduate programs in the U.S. Many of these students want to hone their language and cross-cultural skills for academic and professional success. Students can make an appointment with a Language
MLT Graduate Student Handbook
Page 42


Development Specialist to get individualized coaching on language or cross-cultural issues. Students can choose from sessions on:
How to give a strong presentation • Writing academic emails • Analyzing expectations and strategies for clear academic writing • How to talk about yourself as a professional in the U.S. • Developing clearer pronunciation • Using accurate grammar • Building fluency
and more. Students can make an appointment with a Language Development Specialist to get individualized coaching on language or cross-cultural issues.
The Student Academic Success Center is also charged with certifying the language of International Teaching Assistants (ITAs), ensuring that nonnative English speakers have the language proficiency needed to succeed as teaching assistants in the Carnegie Mellon classroom. Students preparing to do an ITA Certification should plan to take classes offered by the language support team at the SASC website or attend a Language Support Orientation at the SASC or in your department.
A.2.4.3 Learning Support
Peer Tutoring: Weekly tutoring appointments are offered one-on-one and small group format to students from any discipline who need assistance with a course that may not be supported by our other services. Weekly appointments give students the opportunity to interact regularly with the same tutor to facilitate deeper understanding of concepts. Students can register online through the Student Academic Success website.
Academic Coaching: Academic Coaching provides holistic one-on-one peer support and group workshops to help students find and implement their conditions for success. We assist students in improving time management, productive habits, organization, stress management, and study skills. Students will request support through the Academic Success Center website and attend in-person meetings or meet using video and audio conferencing technology to provide all students with support.
“Just in Time” Workshops: The Student Academic Success team is available to partner with instructors and departments to identify skills or concepts that would benefit from supplemental offerings (workshops, boot camps) to support students’ academic success and learning. We are eager to help convene and coordinate outside of the classroom skill-building opportunities that can be open to any student interested in building skill or reinforcing course concept mastery.
MLT Graduate Student Handbook
Page 43


A.2.5 Office of Research Integrity & Compliance
www.cmu.edu/research-compliance/index.html The Office of Research Integrity & Compliance (ORIC) is designed to support research at Carnegie Mellon University. The staff work with researchers to ensure research is conducted with integrity and in accordance with federal and Pennsylvania regulation. ORIC assists researchers with human subject research, conflicts of interest, responsible conduct of research, export controls, intellectual property rights and regulations, and institutional animal care & use. ORIC also consults on, advises about and handles allegations of research misconduct.
A.3 Key Offices for Health, Wellness & Safety
A.3.1 Counseling & Psychological Services
https://www.cmu.edu/counseling Counseling & Psychological Services (CaPS) affords the opportunity for students to talk privately about academic and personal concerns in a safe, confidential setting. An initial consultation at CaPS can help clarify the nature of the concern, provide immediate support, and explore further options if needed. These may include a referral for counseling within CaPS, to another resource at Carnegie Mellon, or to another resource within the larger Pittsburgh community. CaPS also provides workshops and group session on mental health related topics specifically for graduate students on campus. CaPS services are provided at no cost. Appointments can be made in person or by telephone at 412-268-2922.
A.3.2 Health Services
www.cmu.edu/HealthServices University Health Services (UHS) is staffed by physicians, advanced practice clinicians, and registered nurses who provide general medical care, allergy injections, first aid, gynecological care and contraception, and on-site pharmaceuticals. The CMU Student Insurance Plan covers most visit fees to see the physicians and advanced practice clinicians & nurse visits. Fees for prescription medications, laboratory tests, diagnostic procedures and referral to the emergency room or specialists are the student’s responsibility and students should review the UHS website and their insurance plan for detailed information about the university health insurance requirement and fees.
UHS also has a registered dietician and health promotion specialists on staff to assist students in addressing nutrition, drug and alcohol, and other healthy lifestyle issues. In addition to providing direct health care, UHS administers the Student Health Insurance Program. The Student Health Insurance plan offers a high level of coverage in a wide network of health care providers and hospitals. Appointments can be made by visiting UHS’s website, walk-in, or by telephone, 412-268-2157.
MLT Graduate Student Handbook
Page 44


A.3.3 Campus Wellness
http://www.cmu.edu/wellness/ At Carnegie Mellon, we believe our individual and collective well-being is rooted in healthy connections to each other and to campus resources. The university provides a wide variety of wellness, mindfulness and connectedness initiatives and resources designed to help students thrive inside and outside the classroom. The BeWell@CMU e-newsletter seeks to be a comprehensive resource for CMU regarding all wellness-inspired events, announcements and professional and personal development opportunities. Sign up for the Be Well monthly newsletter via https://bit.ly/BeWellNewsletter or by contacting the Program Director for Student Affairs Wellness Initiatives, at alusk@andrew.cmu.edu.
A.3.4 Religious & Spiritual Life Initiatives (RSLI)
www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/spirituality Carnegie Mellon is committed to the holistic growth of our students, including creating opportunities for spiritual and religious practice and exploration. We have relationships with local houses of worship from various traditions and many of these groups are members of CMU’s Council of Religious Advisors. We also offer programs and initiatives that cross traditional religious boundaries in order to increase knowledge of and appreciation for the full diversity of the worldview traditions. Our RSLI staff are here to support students across the spectrum of religious and spiritual practice and would be more than happy to help you make a connection into a community of faith during your time at CMU.
A.3.5 University Police
http://www.cmu.edu/police/ 412-268-2323 The University Police Department is located at 4551 Filmore Street. The department’s services include police patrols and call response, criminal investigations, fixed officer and foot officer patrols, event security, crime prevention and education programming, and bicycle and laptop registration. Visit the department’s website for additional information about the staff, emergency phone locations, crime prevention, lost and found, fingerprint services, and annual statistic reports.
Carnegie Mellon University publishes an annual campus security and fire safety report describing the university’s security, alcohol and drug, sexual assault, and fire safety policies and containing statistics about the number and type of crimes committed on the campus and the number and cause of fires in campus residence facilities during the preceding three years. Graduate students can obtain a copy by contacting the University Police Department at 412- 268-6232. The annual security and fire safety report is also available online at https://www.cmu.edu/police/annualreports/.
MLT Graduate Student Handbook
Page 45


A.3.6 Shuttle & Escort Services
Parking and Transportation coordinates the Shuttle and Escort Service provided for CMU students, faculty, and community. The Shuttle & Escort website has full information about these services, stops, routes, tracking, and schedules. https://www.cmu.edu/parking/shuttle/index.html
A.4 The WORD
http://www.cmu.edu/student-affairs/theword/
The WORD is Carnegie Mellon University’s student handbook and serves as the foundation for the department (and sometimes college) handbook. The WORD contains University-wide academic policies and resources, community policies and resources, and describes the University-level procedures used to review possible violations of these standards. It is designed to provide all students with the tools, guidance, and insights to help you achieve your full potential as a member of the Carnegie Mellon community. Information about the following is included in The WORD (not an exhaustive list) and graduate students are encouraged to bookmark this site and refer to it often:
Carnegie Mellon Vision, Mission Statement of Assurance Carnegie Mellon Code Academic Standards, Policies and Procedures
Educational Goals Academic and Individual Freedom Academic Disciplinary Actions Overview Statement on Academic Integrity Standards for Academic & Creative Life Assistance for Individuals with Disabilities Master’s Student Statute of Limitations Conduct of Classes Copyright Policy Cross-college & University Registration Doctoral Student Status Policy Evaluation & Certification of English Fluency for Instructors Final Exams for Graduate Courses Grading Policies Intellectual Property Policy Privacy Rights of Students Student’s Rights
